newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Record price paid for Portuguese painting.
newsitem.headline: Record price paid for Portuguese painting.

text.p: An anonymous buyer has paid a record price of 42 million escudos ($253,000) for a Portuguese painting, a 1910 oil canvas by renowned local artist Jose Malhoa depicting a drunk.

"This work, 'Enough, My Father!', is a record price paid in Portugal. This is one of the best works of Malhoa," Clara Ferreira Marques, partner of auctioneers Leiria & Nascimento, told Reuters after the auction on Thursday night.
The painting, rich in colour, shows a young woman pleading to her drunken father in a bar to stop drinking.

Malhoa (1855-1933), who painted scenes of villagers and farmhands, was a leading Portuguese impressionist and was hailed in his time as one of Portugal's greatest artists. Many of his works are displayed in national museums and galleries today.

Another Malhoa oil painting, 'Give a Drink to the Thirsty', dated 1921, which shows a young woman watering a plant, was sold at the same auction for 26 million escudos ($157,000), a record price before 'Enough, My Father' was sold in the next lot.

A third, small oil painting by Malhoa, 'A couple of Birds', dated 1920, sold for 7.4 million escudos ($45,000) at the packed auction, where porcelain tableware, sculptures, antique clocks and paintings by other artists also came up for sale.
The previous record price for a Portuguese painting was 25 million escudos ($150,000), paid last year for another Malhoa painting, Ferreira Marques said.
A painting by Maria Helena Vieira da Silva, perhaps the best known Portuguese artist who has a museum dedicated to her work in Lisbon, has sold for 24 million escudos ($145,000), she said.
Ferreira Marques said the record price was paid because one of Malhoa's best works had come to the market, rather than because an art boom was starting in Portugal.
"Just as the best Van Gogh paintings sell for very high prices and his less impressive works sell for much less, the same is true of Malhoa's paintings," she said.

The Portuguese have more money to spend on paintings as disposable income has risen sharply in recent years. The economy is showing a robust performance as it strives to pass the tough entry test for joining a European single currency.
The Malhoa paintings had belonged to a wealthy Portuguese private collector, Agostinho Fernandes. ($1=165.79 escudos)
